message: Congratulations, your baby's here! Give him the best by breastfeeding. If he refuses to feed or has difficulty breathing, go to the hospital
It is important that your baby gets the BCG, hepatitis B and polio vaccines this week! Ensure your baby gets it at the hospital
Keep the cord clean and dry to prevent infection. Clean it with methylated spirit and leave it uncovered. If it is red or smelly, go to the hospital
Keep your baby quiet and warm. If his body or eyes are yellow go to the hospital immediately!
Let your baby feed often. He needs a good mouthful of breast to get your milk. You will see his jaw moving as he feeds and hear him swallow
Circumcision is meant for boys not girls! Do not circumcise your girl child as it cause excessive bleeding and even have harmful effects in future
Some bleeding after birth is normal. But if you soak more than 2-3 pads in 20 minutes or the bleeding gets heavier, go to the hospital
Look out for signs of infection. If your discharge smells, your tummy hurts or you have a fever, go to the hospital for help
Are you irritable and weepy? This is quite common among new mothers. Talk to someone about it, get some rest, and make sure you eat well
Your breastmilk is making your baby strong. Feed him 8-10 times a day, with night time feeds too. Don't give him water or anything else
A well fed baby will have a full belly and a sleepy smile! During growth spurts he will feed more. This will increase your milk supply
The longer your baby feeds each time, the richer your milk will become. Let him fall asleep on the breast. You can rest while you feed
Your baby will look into your eyes now as you talk to him. If he is too weak and unresponsive, take him to the clinic to get checked out
You can be sure your baby's getting enough milk if he wets 6-8 nappies daily. If not, feed him more and get him checked at the hospital
After a feed, your breasts should feel soft and empty. Let your baby feed until he comes off the breast, so he gets lots of lovely milk
Do you have sore, pink, cracked nipples? It could be a yeast infection. Go to the clinic with your baby. You will both need treatment
Vaccines protect your baby against diseases which can kill. Next week your baby will need vaccines. Take him to the clinic for them.
You should feel stronger now. If you have smelly or painful discharge or bleeding, visit the clinic. Take iron pills for another 2 months
Remember to take your baby to the hospital to get the polio and pentavalent vaccines this week
Feed your baby ONLY breastmilk. This prevents pregnancy until your baby turns 6 months as long as your menses haven't returned
When you pick your baby up, you will notice he is getting heavier. This is a good sign. Your milk alone is helping him grow
When you talk to your baby, he'll respond by waving his arms and legs. Take him to the clinic every month to make sure he is growing well
Is your baby too weak, pale or not feeding well? He is ill. Keep him warm with a blanket and hat and go to the hospital
The milk at the start of a feed is thin. The longer he feeds the richer your milk gets. Rich milk aids growth
Keep your baby off the ground, away from direct sunlight. Put him on his tummy on a clean blanket or mat to play. He can lift his head now
Stools have germs that cause many diseases. Get rid of stools safely and wash your hands with soap afterwards. This prevents illness
Your baby does not need water even when it's hot. Your breastmilk has all the water he needs, and it's clean and safe. Water may not be
Your baby is 2-months-old. Your precious milk will help him gain nearly a kilo this month. Keep breastfeeding. He needs nothing else
Are your baby's stools suddenly loose and watery? Breastfeed him often and see your health worker. Give extra breastfeeds after he recovers
Your baby's next set of vaccines are due next week. Take him to the clinic for them. If he cries soon after, your breastmilk will help soothe him
Make sure you take your baby to the hospital to be receive the oral polio and pentavalent vaccines this week
Swaddle your baby with a cotton cloth to help him feel warm and secure. But don't swaddle her too tightly or cover her face. It may suffocate him
Your doctor may give you iron and folic-acid pills to take for the next few months. They will help you recover from the birth
Baby crying? Try breastfeeding him, swaddling or rocking him gently. These will all help to soothe him
Take some time every day to watch your baby breathing. If it is rapid and shallow, he may be ill and need treatment at the clinic
Crying is normal for babies, but if your baby is crying non-stop or cries strangely, get him checked at the hospital. He may be ill
Your baby loves the sound of your voice. Talk and sing to him every day. Make eye contact and smile. He will smile back!
A fever, shivering and rapid breathing are signs of an ill baby. Go to the clinic. They will give the right medicine
Your breasts may feel softer now. Don't worry, you still have plenty of milk. Your body now knows just how much milk your baby needs
Vaccines are safe! The risk of serious side effects is very small compared to the benefits. Ensure you take your baby to the hospital to be vaccinated next week
You can express breastmilk and leave it for someone else to feed your baby with a spoon. Keep your milk in a very clean container for up to 6 hours
Are you feeling sad all the time? Talk to your health worker about this. Ask your family to help?you eat well and get plenty of rest
Your baby probably loves hearing voices. Why not sing a lullaby or tell him a bed-time story before bed today? Dads can join in as well
Your baby's next set of polio and pentavalent vaccines are due. They will help protect against many diseases. Take them at the hospital
Let your baby sleep inside an insecticide-treated net so mosquitoes don't bite him.  If the net has a hole, stitch a piece of cloth over it
Your baby is looking at the world around him now. Give him different toys and objects to look at. Keep his toys clean
Wash your hands before cooking and eating and after using the toilet. Set up a washstand with soap and water near the kitchen and toilet
If your baby has diarrhoea, breastfeed him more. If it lasts over a day, visit the hospital. He may need oral rehydration salts (ORS) and zinc
Your baby can see more clearly now. He can see your clothes and hair and will try to grab them! If his eye gets infected, visit the hospital
Smoke from cooking inside can lead to breathlessness and illness. Open windows when cooking to keep you and your baby healthy
Your body is able to make as much breastmilk as your baby wants. Feed him only your breastmilk whenever he wants. He needs nothing else
A routine helps your baby to know what to expect. It also helps you manage your time. Stick to roughly the same time and length for naps
Put your baby to sleep on him back. This is the most important way to help your baby sleep safely through the night
Protect your baby from mosquitoes. Dress him in light coloured clothing. Use an insecticide-treated bednet every night. Fit window screens
If your baby gets a cold, breastmilk will help him recover. Try feeding him sitting up. It will make it easier if he has a blocked nose
Breast milk is great for mothers too. It prevents breast and ovarian cancer. So breastfeed your baby today!
Is your baby teething? Let him suck on a clean finger to ease the pain. Wipe any drool off his chin with a soft, clean cloth
Your baby is making lots of noises now as he tries to copy words. Try encouraging him by talking to him during the day
Babies who are inactive, grunting, feverish or a blue colour are ill. If your baby has these signs, take him to the clinic quickly
Is your baby playful and feeding and sleeping well? These are signs he's healthy! Take him to the clinic if he is too weak or not feeding
Your baby's skin is very sensitive to the sun. Make sure you cover him with a hat and long cotton clothes in sunny weather
Keep your baby away from smoke, from the fire and from cigarettes - all can make it hard for him to breathe
Make your home safe for your baby. Check that there are no small objects on the floor and keep sharp objects out of reach
Babies love to laugh. Try making your baby giggle by playing with him and pulling silly faces. It is a sign that he is developing well
Thinking about having another baby?  Wait at least two years so your next baby is healthy. Find out about family planning now
You need iron to stay strong and healthy. Try to eat green leafy vegetables, beans or meat every day. These foods contain lots of iron
Your baby's first tooth will be coming through soon. He may like it if you rub his sore gums with your clean finger
If your baby tries to bite at the breast, pull him in close to you. Your breast will cover his nose and make him let go to breathe
Your baby still needs only your breastmilk. Don't be tempted to give him any other foods or liquids until he is six months old
Play peek-a-boo with your baby today. He'll love it. He's learning how an object might still be there even if it disappears
Putting your baby to sleep on pillows can be dangerous. He may slip under them and suffocate. He doesn't need one yet
Your periods might return soon. Talk to your doctor about family planning methods. Space your babies for their health and yours
Around now your baby will begin to recognise his own name. Watch and you will see him turn when you call his name.
Breastfeeding is the best thing you can do for your baby. In a few weeks, he will be ready to try some other foods and water, but not yet
Enjoy the baby you have - he'll only be a baby for a short while. Spacing your family gives you time to help each baby develop and learn
Let your baby lie on a clean floor to protect him from infection. Clean the floor with soap and water or put him on a clean blanket
Look out for signs of illness. If your baby vomits more than 5 times during a day, go to the clinic. Give her plenty of extra breastfeeds
Germs can cause nasty infections. You can help prevent them by washing your hands with water and soap after changing nappies
Slowly but surely your baby is becoming more independent. He may roll over already. Before you know it, he'll be crawling and walking!
Next week you can try giving your baby mashed foods. Get a cup, a small spoon and a dish ready. Wash them well. Do not use a bottle
Your milk is still your baby's main source of food, even after he starts eating soft food. Keep breastfeeding, it protects him from illness
Now your baby is 6 months, he can have some soft, mashed foods. Give him mashed fruit, vegetables or thick porridge 2-3 times a day
Your baby's stools have germs which can make him ill. Dispose of his stools properly to keep your baby safe
Your baby may become attached to a toy, blanket or even a piece of cloth. This comforts him and helps him to become independent
Hand washing helps keep your family healthy. Set up a washstand with soap and water near where you prepare food
Protect your baby from diarrhoea. Make sure his food is well-cooked and fresh. Give him only clean, safe water
Beans and eggs are a great source of energy for your baby now. Mash them up with other vegetables and offer them 2-3 times a day
Your baby can hold toys well now and pass them from hand to hand. He may also learn how to clap his hands!
Teething can be painful. Rub a clean finger over his gums to numb the pain. Put some cream on his chin to protect it from drool
With a baby to look after, it is easy to forget about yourself. Eat well and get some gentle exercise every day. It will keep you healthy
Your baby now begins to understand when you are happy or sad. If you're sad, he may be sad, too. If you are laughing, he may join in
Your baby will be teething soon. If he bites when feeding, take him off the breast and say 'no' loudly! Don't stop feeding him your milk
As a mother, you will know when something is wrong with your baby. Trust your intuition and go to the hospital for help
Your baby is now on the move. Keep an eye on him as he plays. Always leave your baby with a responsible adult, to prevent accidents
There are many safe, modern, reliable methods to space babies. Get them for free at the clinic or the pharmacy or from a health worker
Your baby is very inquisitive now and wants to explore. Keep drugs and poisonous substances in child-proof containers and out of his reach
Your baby may love playing with animals, but they are dirty. If he strokes any animals, wash his hands with soap and water afterwards
If your baby swallows anything poisonous, like kerosene or detergents, rush to the hospital. Take some of what he has swallowed with you
Having a baby will change your relationship with your partner. You can stay close by making some time for each other every day
If your baby has diarrhoea, breastfeed him after every loose stool. When he is better, give him an extra meal every day for 2 weeks
Your baby is too precious to take risks with. If he is ill, go to the clinic for good care. Don't wait! Babies can get ill very quickly
Leaving your baby with someone else can be hard. But it will give you some time to yourself and will help him learn how to socialise
With your baby shuffling, crawling or standing, he is bound to get a few bumps! A kiss and a cuddle will soon set him right again
Prevent burns by keeping your baby out of the cooking area. If he gets burnt, wash the burn with cold water. Go to the clinic for treatment
For your baby's safety, cover water containers with a lid, clear the floor of objects he can swallow, and keep sharp objects out of reach
Your baby could be exploring different objects by shaking, banging and throwing them. Playtime may get a bit noisy!
Before drinking water or using it to cook, boil it to clean it. This will kill germs and will keep your baby safe and healthy
You can now give your baby food 3-4 times a day. Try mashing potato with meat, eggs, fish or beans. Keep breastfeeding!
Disciplining your baby can be hard, but it is necessary sometimes. Be firm but don't shout. Put him in an area where he can calm down
Chest pain and a cough that lasts over three weeks are signs of TB. You can protect your baby by getting treatment from the clinic
If a family member has TB, take your baby to the clinic for preventive medicine. This will prevent him from catching TB, too
Your baby should be sitting confidently now. He may even be trying to pull himself up ready to stand. If he is not, go to the clinic
It is time for your baby to get the measles and yellow fever vaccines. Take him to the clinic to get him protected
If your baby gets bitten or scratched by an animal, get him checked at the clinic. Clinic staff can help prevent infection
Your baby should be getting Vitamin A this month. Take your baby to the hospital this week to get it, along with the measles and yellow fever vaccines
Help your baby fall asleep alone. Don't rock him to sleep. Put him down when he's sleepy. If he wakes, don't go to him straight away. Stay quiet
Feeling tired? Rest when your baby naps, drink plenty of clean water and make sure you eat well. Ask your family to help with baby care
Your baby's babble may have started sounding like proper words now. Keep talking to your baby so he can learn more
Your baby should have gotten the measles and yellow fever vaccines by now. If not, make sure your baby gets them immediately
If your baby is standing and gripping the furniture, he may be trying to walk. Encourage him by holding his hands while he walks
Many babies crawl by this age, but some never crawl and go straight to walking. Both are normal. Make sure he is safe now he's exploring.
Don?t give excuses! Ensure your baby has gotten the measles and yellow fever vaccines in a hospital by now
Your partner may feel left out. Suggest he gives the baby his baths. That will help them both bond. It'll also be fun!
Your baby is starting to understand simple words. Keep talking to him and encourage him to talk. He'll soon be able to answer you!
ORS made up with clean water is vital when your baby has diarrhoea. ORS won't cure it, but will restore the water your baby is losing
Protect your baby from dehydration by giving him lots of clean water. Keep him inside on hot days. Dress him in loose cotton clothes, too
If your baby has a cold, a fever and pulls his ear, it could be an ear infection. Don't put anything in his ear. Take him to the clinic
You can now give your baby food 3-4 times a day. Try mashing potato with meat, fish or beans and give fruit or eggs. Keep breastfeeding!
Your baby probably keeps you up at night. Try to get some sleep when he sleeps. You'll feel better
If your baby is hot, irritable and feeding poorly, he may have a fever. Take him to the clinic
If your baby's forehead, chest or back feel hot, bathe him in cool water. Give him plenty of breastmilk or clean water
If your baby has a fever that lasts more than a day, take him to the hospital immediately. Staff there can help
Your baby now understands simple instructions. That doesn't mean he'll listen! He's exploring his independence
If your baby gets a cut, wash it well to prevent infection. Then rub some antiseptic cream. You can get antiseptic cream at the clinic
If your baby's eyes are sticky or pink, he may have an eye infection. Bathe his eyes in cool clean water. Go to the clinic
Wash fruit and vegetables to remove dirt and germs. Use boiled water and wash them well before feeding them to your baby
If your child refuses to eat, be patient. Don't force him. Give him fresh foods with lots of colours, tastes and textures
Food that has gone bad can cause diarrhoea and make your baby ill. Buy fresh foods always!
New foods may make your baby's stools hard. Feed her mashed fruit. Give her boiled water from a cup, not a bottle. Breastfeed her whenever she wants
Even though your baby is eating solids, breastmilk is still an important part of his food. Keep breastfeeding until he is 2 years old
Diarrhoea makes your baby lose lots of fluid. Help him recover by breastfeeding. Take him to the clinic for ORS and zinc
Your baby may be crawling everywhere. Expect bumps and bruises now your baby is mobile
Your baby is nearly 1 year old. Good job! He needs more food now. Start giving him the food you eat
It can take many tries before your baby learns to enjoy a new food. Introduce foods one at a time, so that you know if anything upsets her stomach
Your baby can now remember things. Play games like peek-a-boo each day and see how quickly he learns them
When your baby's unwell, members of your community may suggest treatment. But don't give your baby anything before checking at the clinic
Offer new foods to your baby every so often. If he refuses, encourage him by trying different food combinations, textures and tastes
Your baby may be able to feed himself with his fingers. Make sure his hands are clean. It may be messy, but try to let him do it himself
Being a mother can be hard sometimes. Why not try talking to your mother or an elder? Don't be scared to ask for help
Your baby's desire to explore is stronger than his desire to listen to your warnings now. Keep your eye on him to keep him safe
Your baby might get scared when you leave him. Say goodbye quickly, with a kiss. He should calm down after you've gone
During the next year your baby will need some more vaccines. Stay in touch with your doctor worker so you know when to go to the clinic
Some worms are picked up from the ground and can make your baby ill. Thick socks or shoes will help protect your baby when he plays outside
There are many ways to prevent getting pregnant too soon. Talk to your doctor to find out more
Keep breastfeeding your baby. He still needs your milk for at least another year. It still has plenty of goodness for him
Your almost one-year-old is very different to the tiny baby you gave birth to, and all because of your loving care. Congratulations!
Happy birthday to your one year old. Remember how small he was as a newborn? You have taken good care of him and helped him grow well
Children who have lots of healthy food live long, happy lives and do well at school. Make sure you give your child the food he needs
Give your baby your precious breastmilk for another year. It will build his strength to fight illness now and in the future
Your baby may now say "dada," "mama," and a few other words. He may use one word for lots of things!
Feed your child the food you serve the rest of your family. Make sure it is mashed or soft. Give him 3-4 meals a day, with snacks too
Each time feed him 3-4 handfuls of rich food, like thick porridge, vegetables or beans. Bread and fruit are good snacks
Your child can tell you what he wants. When he wants to get down, he'll point; when he wants your attention, he'll tug your skirt
It?s common for children to catch worms from the ground. Clinics offer regular deworming treatments. Get your child dewormed at the clinic
Prevent your child catching worms from the ground. Dress him in thick socks or shoes when he plays outside. Or let him play on a blanket
Hold your hands together and let your child pull them apart. It?s a good game! Notice how much stronger he is getting as his muscles grow
Feed your child lots of different vegetables, meat and dairy foods. Your child needs a variety of food to grow well
Feed your child 3-4 handfuls of food every meal. Vegetables, meat and a little oil added to some porridge make a tasty meal
Try to interact with your child constantly. It will help him learn to talk. It will make him happy too! Ask your caregivers, too
Does your child have a blocked nose? Put a cloth to his nose and block one nostril with your finger Ask him to blow
Does your child have a sore throat? Feed him soft food. You could also try offering his favourite foods. This will encourage him to eat
Your child will take his first steps soon, if he hasn?t already. All children are different. He will develop at his own pace
Try to feed your child and your family fresh food that looks and smells good. Eating stale food can cause infections like diarrhoea
Keep goats and chickens out of the kitchen to prevent germs in your food. Shoo them away and wash your hands before cooking to stay healthy
Feed your child small snacks 1-2 times a day, between meals. Fruit, bread, yoghurt, biscuits and crackers are all good snack options
It?s best to wait at least another year before you try for another baby. Use this time to enjoy the child you have
You can delay pregnancy by using family planning methods. There are many methods available. Discuss your options with a doctor
Your child is getting better at using his hands. Don't be too surprised if he rubs mud or dust into the walls! He is testing his new skills
If your child is unwell, give him your precious breastmilk. It will give him the strength to fight the illness. It will comfort him too
After illness, give your child one extra meal a day for the next two weeks. Continue until he regains any lost weight
Babies like to climb but need to be safe. Hold your child's arms, and help him climb over cushions or blankets so he can climb safely
Take your child to the clinic regularly to check if he is growing well. A doctor will answer any questions you may have on feeding
Measure your child's upper arm every month with a piece of string. If his arm grows, then he is growing well. If not, give him more food
Is your child still waking you up at night? Sing him back to sleep with a soothing lullaby. This will comfort him
Boil water before drinking it. Keep boiled water in clean containers and keep them covered. Scoop the water with clean cups
Use a separate bowl for your child's food. After use, wash it straightaway with hot, soapy water. This will prevent infections
Keep breastfeeding your child, especially at night. Breastmilk gives him lots of nutrients. It even helps develop his brain and stomach!
Your child's stools have germs which can make him ill. Dispose of stools in a toilet. Always wash your hands afterwards
Toilets and stools are home to germs. Try to keep toilets clean. This will prevent germs from breeding
Your child may be able to wave bye-bye. First he will copy you, but soon he will recognise the word ?bye-bye? and wave when you say it
Set some money aside for emergency trips to the hospital. Start saving now so you won?t have to worry about paying for transport later
Fever, rash, shivering or fast breathing are signs of illness. If he is too weak, it is an emergency so go to the hospital straight away
Fill a small jar with raw rice or raw beans. Put the lid on and let your child shake it. It?s a noisy game but fun!
Green vegetables, beans and egg yolks are good sources of iron. Serve with fruits like orange and pineapple. They help to absorb the iron
Set up a washing stand with soap and water near to where you prepare food and near the toilet. This will help you regularly wash your hands
Give your child wooden spoons to bang together. Show him how. It may be noisy, but it will help him to develop grip and coordination
Small children's tastes change often. What he may hate now, he may love in a month! So it's worth trying hated foods again
If he is a slow eater, take your time and sit and talk to him while he eats. Eating is a new skill he has to learn. Be patient
Does your child bite? He's not trying to be naughty. Crouch to his level, and say "no" firmly. Do this whenever he bites. He will soon stop
Keep your child away from anyone who coughs and sneezes. Many illnesses are spread through coughs and sneezes, including pneumonia
Take your child to the clinic for treatment when he shows signs of illness. A cough and breathing difficulty means that he is ill
Soon your baby will manage to hold a cup and drink from it. Give him a little water in a cup. Help him tip the cup and sip from it
Make feeding time fun. Make eye contact, smile and talk to your child. You will help him to eat and to learn at the same time
Make sure your child gets the Vitamin A oral drops this month. He needs it!
Your 15-month-old understands a great deal of what you say, but can't talk back to you. Encourage him to learn, by talking to him
Give your child clean and safe drinks. Boil water to make it clean. Boil animal milks before giving them to your child
Take your child to the clinic this week for Vitamin A. This is a liquid medicine given as drops into his mouth
This week, tell your child a bedtime story. You can make it up as you tell it! Your child will still enjoy it
Try to offer new foods to your child often. Try mixing foods he likes with new ones
On a hot day, give your child plenty of clean water to prevent dehydration. Boil the water and then cool it before giving it to your child
Your child may understand what things are for. He may use a hairbrush to try and brush his hair, but a broom to try and sweep the floor
Make mealtimes fun. While feeding, name the utensils used, foods, tastes and colours. Show how some things are big and some are small
Measure your child's upper arm with a tape. Note the size, and measure again in a month. If he hasn't grown, give him more food
Children have great imaginations. Anything can become a toy! Just make sure it's clean, not small enough to choke on and has no sharp edges.
You can prevent infections by washing your child's hands before she eats. Dirty hands in the mouth can cause diarrhea
Let your child touch and pick up food. She may enjoy feeding herself! Encourage her with a smile and say 'that is very good'.
Does your child do the same thing, repeatedly? This is because his memory isn't very good yet. Try to be patient, this is a phase!
If your child has diarrhoea, Salt Sugar Solution can save the day! Add 10 level teaspoons of sugar and 2 level teaspoons of salt to 1L of water
Do you know a household tape and weighing scale is all you need to have a healthy child? Monitor his growth today for strong and healthy living
Over the next few weeks your child may drop one of her daytime naps. Give her a quiet time instead, with a cuddle and a song or story
Make sure all food you feed your child is fresh. If it smells or looks different, it may have spoiled. Spoiled food can cause sickness
Wash fruit and vegetables to remove dirt and germs. Wash them well before feeding them to your child
If your child complains of pain while passing stools and if his stools are dry, hard and small, he may be constipated. Give him plenty of water
If your child is constipated, feed him lots of clean water, fresh fruit juice, beans, lentils and pulses. They help to soften his stools
If your child?s constipation does not improve after a few days, take him to the clinic for medicine. Don?t give him any other medicine.
Talk and sing to your child as much as you can. This will help him learn to talk. Encourage your family members to do the same
Make time for your child during meal times. Quality time with the family helps your child enjoy mealtimes and be confident in the future.
Ask your family members to help with chores so you have more time with your baby. Your baby learns from you and your family
Sit in front of your child and make silly faces, like sticking your tongue out. This will make him laugh. He might even copy you!
Open the windows while cooking to let the smoke out of the house. Smoke in the house can harm your child?s lungs and make him ill
Keep your children in a room away from the kitchen area when you are cooking. Cooking makes smoke, and breathing in smoke is harmful
Wash your child's dirty clothes with soap and water and dry them well. Clean clothes will help protect him from infection
Loose, watery stools are a sign of diarrhoea.  Give him lots of breastmilk and clean water. Let him rest whenever he needs to
If your child has diarrhoea for more than one day, go to the clinic for ORS, medicine and Zinc
Your child has plenty of energy. Chase him outside. Grab him and hug him when you catch him. Watch him laugh!
Never leave your child alone near water. Small children can drown easily. If you do leave, make sure a responsible adult is watching him.
Cover wells that your child could access. He could fall in and get injured or drown. Cover wells with anything that your child can't move.
Is your child attached to a particular toy or object? This is normal. It helps your child to feel safe and secure.
Undernutrition can affect your child?s survival, growth and development. Please ensure to monitor growth of one of the leaders of tomorrow
Your child is undergoing a period of rapid growth. Proteins & vitamins are needed; milk, fruits, vegetables & meat are good sources
Make a ball of newspaper. Roll the ball to your child, and encourage him to roll it back to you. It helps him develop coordination skills
If you use firewood to cook, dry it before you use it. This will minimize the amount of smoke that is made by cooking
Soak your beans overnight before cooking them. This will make reduce cooking time and reduce the amount of smoke created by cooking
Your child is learning how to put 2 words together, such as "me want". Give him lots of praise! Each week he will learn new words
Take your child for an HIV test, if you feel he may be affected. Knowing early will help you give your child the best care possible
Does your child have HIV? Make sure he takes ART medicine every day. Ask your doctor if he needs other medicines as well
Turn old food containers or boxes into toys. Your child can stack them on top of each other. Make sure they're clean, with no sharp edges
Is your child heavier? It's because of all the wonderful food that you are feeding him. Carry on giving him lots of different foods
You can tell your child is healthy if his weight steadily increases. If his weight is the same or reducing, seek advice at the clinic
Does your child shout? Show him how to hold his finger to his lips and say ?shhh?. Play at whispering in his ear and let him whisper to you
Keep stored drinking water covered. This will protect it from animals, dust and dirty hands. Keep scoops and dippers clean too
Keep your food and utensils covered. This will protect them from rats, mice, cockroaches, flies and dust
Does your child have a blocked nose? It could make it hard for him to eat. Help him to gently blow his nose
Keep your stoves clean all the time. After cooking, remove all remnants of food on the stove. This will minimize smoke when cooking.
Cover your cooking pots with a lid during cooking and afterwards. This will keep the heat in and make cooking faster
Your child's arm and leg muscles are strong enough for him to try to climb things. Let him climb safely on an armchair or some cushions.
Cook in areas away from the rest of the family so they do not breathe in too much smoke. Breathing smoke can make your child ill
Try to keep your cooking stove at waist height. This way you won't need to lean over the fire and breathe in smoke. Smoke can make you ill
Jumping will help your child develop his coordination. Mark spots on the ground, and get your child to jump from one to the other
Your child may enjoy using a spoon to eat. It may be messy at first, but it will help develop his hand control if you let him feed himself.
It can be tough feeding a child who refuses to eat. But be patient and keep trying. Talk to him gently as you feed him
Soon, your child may recognize when he needs to urinate. Praise him when he does this. This is a big step towards growing up!
Block access to areas of water, like wells and ponds. You could build a fence around your home. This will protect your child from drowning
If your child was submerged in water, and was unconscious, take him to the clinic as fast as you can. In the meantime, keep him warm
Your child understands the idea of ?pretend? now. Put a sock on your hand to make a puppet. Talk to him in a funny voice!
Don?t store your cooking fuel in drinks bottles like Coca-Cola bottles. Your child may drink from it by mistake
Don't leave the handles of pots with hot liquid in facing outward. Your child may reach for the handle and tip the hot liquid onto her.
Your child will learn as many as ten new words each day. Help him by repeating the names of objects as you point to them.
Hold your child's hand when crossing roads. This will stop your child from running across busy roads, and being run over
Always watch over children playing outdoors near roads. Encourage your neighbours to do the same. This will prevent accidents
Fever and frequent or infrequent urination are signs of an infection. If you see any of these signs in your child take him to the hospital
If your child has a bladder infection, he can get medicines at the clinic. Make sure he takes all his doses for the infection to clear
After she passes urine or stools, wipe your child?s bottom from front to back. This will prevent germs from entering her bladder
Encourage older siblings to play or feed your child. This will encourage them to protect and care for each other when they are older
Is your child coughing a lot, and vomiting afterwards? Take him to the hospital. He may need medical treatment
Sick children need extra care. Let him have plenty of rest, breastmilk, clean water and food. And lots of your love and affection too!
Teach your child how to wash his hands. Help him wet them and lather soap. Make sure he does this after using the toilet and before eating
Check how safe your home is. Block access to balconies, or areas that your child could fall from. Make your home safe for your active child
Make a safe play area for your child. Remove any furniture with sharp corners, or anything he may be tempted to climb
This week, sing a song with your child. Choose something happy and fast. You could clap and dance too! Your child will love it
Don't feed your child fizzy drinks, ice cream, tea, coffee, sweets and candies. They have no goodness in them and harm your child's growth
Food that remains on plates can cause sickness. Wash plates, cups and cutlery well. If food sticks on plates, soak them in boiling water
Bend down when you talk to your child, so he can see your face clearly. It helps him work out the words you are using
Sleep under an insecticide-treated net to keep mosquitoes away. Malaria is passed by mosquitoes at night
Mosquitoes are attracted to still water. Pour away any unused containers or vases of water in and around your home
You may wish to stop breastfeeding your child, but your child needs your breastmilk at least until he is 2. Keep breastfeeding your child!
If you plan to stop breastfeeding your child, reduce the number of feeds slowly, over a few months. Stopping suddenly will upset your child
Let your child breastfeed if he is ill even if he?s stopped breastfeeding. This is because your milk comforts him and helps him recover
Your child can draw lines and circles with a stick in the sand. Draw together. It will help him learn how to write when he is older
Worms are picked up from the ground and make your child ill. Thick socks or shoes will help protect your child when he plays outside
Put your child on a blanket on the floor to keep him away from dirt and germs. Make sure he cannot reach anything that will harm him
Give your child lots of praise when he attempts something new. Your praise will encourage him to keep trying. He wants to impress you!
You can breastfeed your child if he is ill, even if he is eating food. Breastmilk helps a sick child recover
If your child is ill and refuses to eat, try giving him the foods he likes in small amounts every 2 hours. This will help him get better
Does your child enjoy emptying bags and boxes? This is frustrating, but he is learning that small objects can fit inside larger objects
Never leave your child alone in places where he could fall and get hurt. This includes balconies, window ledges, roof tops and stairways
Does your child sleep on a raised bed? Place cushions on the floor next to the bed. This way, he won't be injured if he falls out of bed
If you and your partner have disagreements, try not to let your child know. It could upset him
Remove sharp objects, detergents or medicine from the floor or where your child plays. Your child will be curious and play with anything
If your child gets a cut, wash it well to prevent infection. Then rub in some antiseptic cream. You can get antiseptic cream at the pharmacy
Your child may nap less often now. He is growing up! He's still growing fast though, so let him sleep whenever he needs to.
On hot days, dress your child in loose cotton clothes. If he seems warm, loosen his clothes, or remove a layer
Protect your child from dehydration. Give him lots of clean water and dress him in loose cotton clothes. Try to keep him in the shade
Make tidying a game! Not only will it help your child learn to grasp, but it will help you too! Give him lots of praise afterwards
Does your child sleep on a raised bed? Put cushions on the floor next to the bed. Now he won't get hurt if he rolls out!
If your child hits his head, and is bleeding, dizzy or disorientated, take him to the clinic. He may need medical treatment
Your child can understand opposites now, like big and small. Make finding opposites a game. It will help when he starts to learn numbers
If your child's forehead, chest or back feel hot, bathe him in cool water. Give him plenty of breastmilk or boiled water
If your child has a fever that lasts more than a day, take him to the clinic immediately. A simple fever could cause a seizure
Your child looks less like a baby now. He's upright, active, taller and slimmer. He should still be eating well and gaining weight
Please remember to make your child?s growth your priority. All he needs is a balanced diet
Vitamin A drops are put into your child's mouth. It's easy and safe. They protect him from illness. Your child needs them every 6 months
Congratulations. Your child is 2! You?ve looked after him well. Over the next year keep him well and see that he gets all his vaccinations
By now, your child will be getting most of his nutrition from family foods. He may still sometimes suckle for comfort or when he is ill
If your child is ill, feed him often. Food and milk will help him get better sooner. Gently encourage him to eat, even if he refuses
Your child is learning lots of new words! It?s normal for his words to be unclear at first. The more you talk to him the more he will learn
Your child needs 4 meals a day. She also needs two snacks like fruit, eggs, bread or yoghurt. Don?t give her sweets or soft drinks
If you've chosen to stop breastfeeding, do it gradually. Stopping suddenly will make your child very upset
You can still breastfeed your child when he's ill. Your breastmilk is still good and won't harm your child, even if you become pregnant
If your child has a stuffy nose, clear his nose before feeding him. This will make easier for him to eat
If your child's throat and mouth are sore, feed him soft foods and extra fluids. He needs to keep feeding to get better
Praise your child's good behaviour, instead of punishing bad behaviour. This is a better way to teach your child rules and discipline
As your child grows, he will slowly need bigger portions. Watch him closely at mealtimes so you can understand if he wants more.
Keep giving your child a variety of foods - cereals, beans, meat, fish and lots of green + orange vegetables - for the nutrients he needs
If your child hears you say ?please? and ?thank you?, he will gradually copy you. Remind him gently and praise him when he remembers
Talk to other mothers and share your experiences with them. Other mothers are a great source of information for tips on raising your child
As a mother, you will know when something is wrong with your child. Trust your intuition and go to the clinic for help
Your child will be chattering now. Some of what he says will make sense, but some won?t. By the time she is 4 all her words will be clear
Your child is too precious to take risks with. If she is ill, go to the clinic for good care. Don't wait. Children can get ill very quickly
Always get your child's medicines from the hospital. If your family suggests other types of medicine, explain to them that the hospital is safest.
Your child is getting taller as his bones grow. Give him foods that make strong bones like milk, cheese, yoghurt and leafy green vegetables
A child with diarrhoea needs food. Feed him extra food and water. If it lasts longer than a day, go to the clinic for ORS and zinc pills
ORS is a solution with some sugar and salt. It helps a child with diarrhoea by restoring the water he is losing. ORS can save his life
Many children eat slowly. If your child doesn?t finish his meal in 30 minutes, don?t make him. Put the food somewhere cool. Try again later
Most insecticide-treated nets can have up to 21 washes before you need another one. Keep count of the number of times you wash them
If it?s stuffy inside a mosquito net, open the windows. The windows will let air in and the net will protect you from the mosquitoes
Create your own song with your child. It will help him learn to talk if you make actions that match the words
You may want to try for another child. But it's best to wait one more year. Continue to use family planning methods
Enjoy the child you have. Spacing your family will give you the time to help each of your children develop and learn
Is your child behaving badly? Think about how your family behaves around your child. Children pick up most of their bad habits by copying!
If your child has been bitten or scratched by an animal, wash the wound with clean water. To prevent infection, take him to the clinic
Make sure your child has all his vaccinations. Vaccinations help to prevent infections even from cuts and bites
Make dressing a game. Your child may enjoy doing up big buttons, pulling t-shirts over his head and putting on socks!
Chest pain and a cough that lasts over three weeks are signs of TB. You can protect your child by getting treatment from the clinic
If your child didn't have the TB vaccine at birth, make sure he gets it now. TB can kill. Ask your family to be screened for TB, too
Is your child climbing and jumping? He wants to test her new balance and coordination. Watch him to make sure he doesn?t get hurt
Do not feed your child food from outside stalls. It could contain germs. Instead, take a snack and clean water with you when you go out
If your child has diarrhoea, he needs thick, nutritious food. Thick food, clean water and rest will help him get well again
It's better to praise good behaviour, than to punish bad behaviour. Your child wants to please you
If your child has a cold, a fever and ear pain, it could be an ear infection. Take him to the clinic for medicines
If your child has an ear infection, don?t put oil or any herbal medicine. It will make it worse. Get the right medicine at the clinic
Give your child a little picture book or some paper and crayon. See how immersed he is in what he's doing! He can concentrate longer now
Get your partner involved in small tasks like bathing and playing with your child. Fathers can play a big role in caring for children
Ask your family members to help you with your daily chores. Being a mother is hard work
By now your child is very good at holding on to small objects and playing with them. He can stack little objects and knock them over, too!
Continue to wash your hands with soap regularly. Lather soap over your hands and wrists. Try to get under your nails too
Teach your child to wash his hands regularly with soap after using the toilet and before eating. Dirty hands can cause infections
If you've told your child "no" to something, don't give in when he cries! If you do, he'll think that crying will get him what he wants
Train your child to pass stools in a latrine. Or let him use a potty and you can dispose of her stools in a latrine. Wash your hands after
Keep all stools away from the home. If there is no latrine, bury the stools or carry the stools far away from your child's play area
Has it been raining? Have fun jumping over puddles with your child. You could even jump over rocks and pavement markings
Cough and fast or difficult breathing are signs of illness. Take your child to the clinic as soon as your child shows these signs
Remember to take your child to the clinic for Vitamin A. He needs vitamin A every 6 months to get protection from illnesses like pneumonia
Tantrums are common with young children. If your child is about to start crying, try to distract him. He'll probably forget what upset him!
Fever, headache, chills and vomiting are signs of illness. If your child shows any of these signs, take him to the clinic get her checked
If your child has malaria make sure he takes all the medicines prescribed at the clinic. With the right treatment, malaria can be cured
Keep reminding your child that talking gets better results than tantrums. Praise him when he makes an effort to communicate with words
Keep your child away from animal and human stools and keep areas where he plays as clean as possible. This prevents germs from spreading
Wash your child's bed linen, towels and clothes with hot water and soap. Clean bedding and clothes helps to prevent infections
Explain to your child why rules are necessary. Tell him that it's not safe to run out into the street without holding a grown-up's hand
If your child's eyes are sticky or pink, it may be an eye infection. Take him to the clinic for treatment. He may be in some pain
If your child has an eye infection, bathe his eyes in cool boiled water to soothe them. Don?t let anyone use your child?s wash cloth
Have you noticed your child using a particular hand more than the other? This will probably be his preference for the rest of his life!
If a family member is coughing a lot, ask them to cough into a cloth and wash the cloth every day. This will stop germs from spreading.
Ask your family members not to spit inside the home. Spitting at home can cause germs to spread and can make your child ill
Encourage your children to wash their own hands. They should use soap and clean water. Teach them to do this before meals
Make a bedtime routine for your child. Doing the same thing at bedtime will help him go to sleep. Perhaps sing a lullaby or tell a story
Is your child a restless sleeper? Put something you wore that day in his bed. It will smell of you, and may help soothe him back to sleep
Other people always have an opinion about how to care for your child. But you know what's best for you and your family
Being a mother is a very important job. Take care of your own health. Eat well, rest and get support from family and friends
Regular check-ups at the clinic help keep you and your child healthy. If you have HIV, you will need extra care
Does your child ignore you? You can teach him to be a good listener. Crouch to his level when you talk to him, and make eye contact
Let your child drink milk straight out of a clean cup. Don?t use a bottle. Bottles are difficult to clean and can cause infections
Food that has mould on it is harmful and should not be eaten. Check food before you feed your child and throw it away if it is mouldy
Does your child get upset when you leave him for a short time? Give him something of yours to hold onto, like a scarf. The smell of you will comfort him
Get another dose of Vitamin A for your child at the clinic. It protects him from illness. He needs at least 10 doses until she is 5
Make sure your child eats a variety of food every day. Eating well helps to build up your child's defenses against illness
Toys can be made out of anything. You could use a screwed up newspaper as a ball. Kick it to your child and encourage him to kick it back
Take your child to the clinic for deworming medicine. Deworming medicine kills any worms your child may have picked up
Make sure your child gets deworming medicine every 6 months. Deworming is safe even if your child has not picked up any worms
Your child's balance is getting much better! He can now hop from one foot to the other.
If your child vomits more than 5 times during a day, go to the clinic. Give him plenty of extra breastfeeds or clean water
Germs can cause nasty infections. You can help prevent infections by always washing your hands with soap before touching your child.
Make mealtimes special. Talk with your child as you feed him, or sing a song. Enjoy this time with your child. It will help him eat more
Blisters around your child?s nose and mouth which burst to form scabs may be a skin infection. Take him to the clinic for medicine
Keep the scabs on your child?s skin clean to prevent it from spreading. Gently wash them with water and soap twice a day and pat them dry
You need to make sure your child eats well, so be patient if she refuses to eat. Talk calmly and let him feed himself with fingers foods
Share feeding tips with your partner so he can help you with the feeding. Your child will be happy and you will have time for other work
Does your child bite when he's angry? Stay calm. Crouch to his level and make eye contact. Tell him that he hurt you and made you sad
Are you still breastfeeding? That's great news! Don't let anyone pressurize you to stop. Your breastmilk is still very good for your child
You can feed your child other types of milk, too. But make sure you boil the milk first, and cool it, before feeding it to your child
Your child can't recognise danger like you can. Cover any containers of water in and around your home so your child doesn?t fall in
Turn clean empty plastic bottles into toy cars. Just make car noises and move them around on the floor. Your child will soon join in
Pale skin and cold and clammy hands and feet are signs your child is losing fluids. Take your child to clinic immediately for ORS and zinc
A child recovering from dehydration will pass more urine and not feel thirsty all the time. Keep giving extra fluids until he gets well
Is your child refusing to brush his teeth or go to bed? This is common. Keep trying, he will soon learn that you mean what you say
Does your child have a blotchy red rash, drowsiness and a fever? Go to the clinic fast. He may need help
Keep your child away from crowded places. He can easily catch infections when he?s among lots of people whose health you?re not sure of
Does your child hit? Don't hit him back. Make eye contact and firmly tell him that he hurt you and made you sad
On hot days, dress your child in loose cotton clothes and make sure he drinks lots of water. This will protect your child from dehydration
If your child gets a heat rash, wipe him with a wet cloth and let the air dry his skin. Go to the clinic for cream to soothe the rash
Your child is curious and adventurous. He will want to explore. Watch him, to make sure he doesn't hurt himself
Take your child to the clinic if he has spotty red bumps that turn into sores in a few hours. Hospital staff will check if it?s chickenpox
If your child has chickenpox, apply the cream you get from the hospital to soothe his spots. Don?t let him scratch them
Teach your child the words for different colours. Do this by pointing to objects and telling him the colour. Get him to repeat after you
Check if your child has had his measles vaccine. If not, take him to the clinic for the vaccine so he gets protected against measles
A reddish-brown rash that starts behind the ears and spreads to the rest of the body is probably measles. Take your child to the clinic
Small children love different colours and textures. You may be surprised what he'll want to play with. Anything can be turned into a toy!
Do not leave your child unattended around fires. He won?t understand that fire is dangerous, and may try to touch the flames
Watch your child next to stoves and cooking fires. He could burn himself. If he does get burnt, pour cool water over the burn
Your child might be ready to start using adult toilets. Show him how to use the lavatory. Be patient. If he's not ready, try again in a few weeks
Are you considering having another baby? Make sure you're ready. Go to the hospital for a checkup to ensure you're in good health
Are you trying to get pregnant? Make sure you have a healthy, varied diet. It will help you have a healthy pregnancy
Be careful offering hot drinks to your child. He could spill them and burn himself. Leave hot drinks to cool before you give them to him
If your child gets burnt, pour cool water over the burn. Do not put anything else on it. If the burn is serious, take him to the hospital
Do not put any traditional ointments or food items on burns, such as butter, oil or herbs. Instead, pour cool, clean water over the burn
Your child is slowly learning to take care of himself. Give him lots of praise whenever he tries something new - even if he doesn't succeed!
If a family member smokes, ask him to smoke outside the house away from your child. Breathing in smoke can cause illnesses like pneumonia
If your child has pneumonia, he can get treatment at the clinic or the local pharmacy. Just 2 tablets twice a day for 5 days
Does your child make the same noise repeatedly? He's not trying to annoy you! This is the way he learns. Be patient, it?s only a phase
Make sure all food you feed your child is fresh. If the smell or appearance has changed, it may have spoiled. Spoiled food can cause sickness
Store food in a cool, dry place. This will keep the food fresh. If food is left in the sun or damp, it can spoil. Spoiled food can cause sickness
Has your child successfully used a latrine? Clap and praise him when he does this. It will encourage him to continue
Does someone else take care of your child? Show them some of our messages. That way, they won't undo all the good work you've done!
Ask caregivers to wash their hands with soap before preparing food and after using the toilet. This will protect your child from illness
Keep trying to give your child lots of different foods. If she doesn't like something one day, she may like it the day after!
Keep your food and utensils covered. This will protect them from rats, mice, cockroaches, flies and dust
Cook meat until the juices run clear. Cook fish until it flakes apart. Raw meat and fish can contain germs, which can harm your family
This week, have fun making rhymes with your child. It will encourage him to learn new words
Keep chemicals and cleaning products out of your child's reach. Children like to put things in their mouths, but chemicals can kill
If your child has swallowed chemicals, take him to the hospital fast. Take the container with you, so doctors know the ingredients
Trust your instincts. If you think your child is unwell, take him to the clinic. You know him better than anyone else, so trust yourself
If your child feels unwell, get him to the hospital for treatment. It's best to get treatment as early as possible
If you feel your child is at risk of HIV, get him tested at the clinic. Knowing early will help you give your child the right care
Is your child still having toilet accidents? Stay calm. Praise him when he uses the toilet correctly. It will encourage him to keep trying
Insecticide-treated nets will protect your child from getting bitten by mosquitoes. Talk to your local NGO about getting one
If your mosquito net has a hole in it, stitch a piece of cloth to cover it. If the hole is too big, try to get a new one
Your child is much more active now! He will love running and exploring. Keep watching her. Small children can easily fall and get hurt
Is your child coughing a lot, and making a whooping sound in between breaths? Take him to the clinic. He may need treatment
Does your child have pale skin and blue lips? Take him to the hospital fast. He may need urgent medical help
Teach your child names of body parts like head, legs and stomach. This will help him describe aches and pain and also teach him new words
Is your water unsafe? You can clean it at home. Bring a pan of water to the boil. Once the water has boiled, it is safe to drink
Boiling water is the best way to clean water. But if it?s difficult to boil, ask your clinic staff about other methods of cleaning water
If you're outside, encourage your child to look at clouds in the sky. Ask him "what are their shapes?", "do they look like anything else?"
Staying healthy is important for your child. Taking care of yourself and regular check-ups at the clinic will keep you well for your child
A child needs his mother's love always. With constant love, affection and care, your child will grow up to be confident and healthy
Do you have a spare bit of rope? Teach your child how to skip! He'll love it. Just make sure he has plenty of room!
Don?t feed your child sweets and sugary snacks. They will ruin your child?s appetite and spoil his teeth.
Give your child plenty of dairy products like milk, yoghurt and eggs. They will help to make your child?s teeth healthy
Is your child waking you up in the middle of the night? He may need to go to bed a bit later now. He's growing up!
Do you ride a bicycle or moped? If you can, wear a helmet. If your child rides with you, she'll need a helmet too. Helmets save lives!
Make sure that your child plays in a safe area away from roads and traffic. This will help to prevent a road accident
By now your child may find it easier to separate from you. If not, say your goodbyes quickly and firmly. Long goodbyes are upsetting
Take your child to the clinic for more Vitamin A drops. These are put into your child's mouth. It's easy and safe
Give your child plenty of colourful fruits and vegetables, as well as meat and dairy. He needs lots of variety with his food
Your child is old enough to learn about road safety. Teach him to look both directions before crossing a road. He should walk slowly
Teach road safety to your child. Tell him to walk towards oncoming traffic, rather than in front of it. He'll be able to see the vehicles
Your child is 3 years! Think of how much your child has accomplished. This is all down to you, and your love and hard work. Well done!
